quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: You're planning a software project. Team says 'We need 2,000 hours to deliver full scope.' Finance says 'Budget is $200K = 1,000 hours at $200/hr.' Your sponsor insists on a 6-month deadline (1,200 hours available). Three constraints, three different numbers. How do you proceed?
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What's your FIRST step?

options.A: Tell the team to work faster‚Äîcompress their estimates
options.B: Develop THREE integrated plans showing scope-down OR budget-up OR schedule-slip scenarios, then present options to sponsor
options.C: Split the difference: reduce scope, add budget, extend schedule slightly
options.D: Choose the sponsor's deadline as the constraint and force everything to fit

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Integration reveals constraints and enables trade-off decisions

insights.explanation: Scope, schedule, and budget plans cannot exist independently. They're interconnected. A realistic plan shows how they're balanced.
insights.pmbokSupport: Project planning is an integrated process. Changes in one area affect others

insights.explanation: Don't guess which constraint is real. Calculate: What if we reduce scope to fit budget+timeline? What if we extend timeline? What if we add budget? Present options with data.
insights.pmbokSupport: Integrated planning provides clear options for sponsor decision-making

insights.explanation: You present options. Sponsor chooses which constraints are fixed. That's leadership. Your job is to show the math and consequences.
insights.pmbokSupport: Stakeholders approve integrated plans and authorize constraints

trapSection.explanation: Unintegrated planning creates false promises and project failure.

trapTable.violation: Assumes estimates are padded. They probably aren't. Risk of failure increases.
Compromises without calculating consequences. Likely to fail on all three fronts.
Overrides scope and budget constraints without sponsor decision
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: PM decides constraints instead of sponsor

checklist: Are all three plans (scope, schedule, budget) aligned?
If not, which constraint is conflicting?
patternRecognition.patternRule: When plans don't align, develop options for sponsor: 'Fix constraint X AND Y, slide constraint Z by this much.' Present with data.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Integration ensures all plans work together toward project success:

rows.action: List what's fixed: schedule, budget, scope, quality, resources. Understand which constraints are firm.
rows.examKeywords: Constraints, Fixed vs. flexible, Sponsor requirements

rows.action: Develop scope, schedule, budget plans separately. Then compare. Do they align? If not, identify gaps.
Create scenarios: 'If we keep scope + budget, timeline is X.' 'If we keep scope + timeline, budget is Y.' Calculate consequences.
Present multiple plans with trade-offs clearly. Don't choose for the sponsor. Show data: 'Option A costs extra $50K,' 'Option B extends schedule 4 weeks.'
rows.examKeywords: Options presentation, Sponsor choice, Trade-off clarity

rows.action: Sponsor chooses which option. Document the approved integrated plan. This becomes the baseline.
Double-check: Can the team deliver this plan? Do we have resources? Are risks acceptable?
rows.examKeywords: Feasibility review, Risk assessment, Realistic planning

rows.action: Ensure scope team, schedule team, and budget team all understand the approved plan and how it's integrated.
keyQuestions: Does everyone understand the integrated plan?

rows.action: Monitor all three plans. If one drifts, others drift too. Early detection of integration problems.
If scope creep occurs but schedule is fixed, budget will increase. Escalate immediately. Don't hide trade-offs.

pmbokConnection.quote: Integrated planning aligns all project constraints and enables informed trade-off decisions

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: Integrated plan = all three (scope, schedule, budget) balanced | Trade-off = fix two constraints, one will adjust | Sponsor decides which constraints are fixed | PM presents options with data | Integration breaks when one constraint changes without rebalancing others
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: Never say 'yes' to a constraint (scope, schedule, budget) without integrating it with the others. Show impact. Get sponsor decision.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Look for 'project plan,' 'constraints conflict,' 'schedule vs. budget,' 'trade-off' ‚Üí Identify all three constraints. Show integration gaps. Present options with data.

secondScenario.title: üéØ Apply I.N.T.E.G.R.A.T.E.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Approved plan: 8-month project, $500K budget, 1,500-hour scope (100 developers √ó 3 months, then 50 √ó 2 months). Month 3 status: only 350 hours complete (behind schedule). Sponsor learns about delay and says 'We must hit the 8-month deadline still.' No mention of budget or scope change. How do you handle this?
secondScenario.question: What's your response?

options.A: It's possible. Push the team harder to catch up
options.B: Develop integrated analysis: To keep 8-month deadline AND $500K budget, scope must reduce to ~800 hours (50% cut). OR extend timeline. OR add budget. Present three options with data
options.C: Apologize and commit to catching up in the next month
options.D: Reduce some quality standards to fit the timeline

quotes.text: Integration is where the magic happens. That's when you stop treating scope, schedule, and budget as separate silos and start seeing them as one connected system.
quotes.author: Andrew Ramdayal

quotes.text: Project integration links all processes and knowledge areas. Changes in one area ripple through the entire project.
quotes.author: PMI

fieldInsights.title: Plans Without Integration are Fiction
fieldInsights.insight: A scope plan, schedule plan, and budget plan that don't align aren't plans‚Äîthey're wishes. True integration shows the real constraints and trade-offs.

fieldInsights.title: Sponsor Decides, PM Informs
fieldInsights.insight: You don't choose constraints. Sponsor does. Your job is to show the math: 'If we keep X and Y fixed, Z will be this.' Then sponsor chooses.

story.title: Integrating Three Mountain Peaks into One Expedition
story.narrative: Your expedition can tackle three goals: reach Peak A (high), reach Peak B (medium), reach Peak C (low). But resources, time, and supplies are limited. Integration is the only way...

scenes.description: Budget: $50K (fixed, sponsor decided). Timeline: 30 days (fixed, permit deadline). Scope: Three peaks to climb. Which is flexible?
Climbing all three peaks requires 40 days and $70K. Budget+timeline are fixed. Scope conflict detected. Can't climb all three.

Option A: Climb Peak A only (highest), $50K, 30 days, success. Option B: Climb Peaks A+C (higher+easier), $50K, 32 days, miss deadline. Option C: Climb A+B but less thoroughly, $50K, 30 days, quality risk.
'Option A: One peak, guaranteed success.' 'Option B: Two peaks, 2-day delay.' 'Option C: Two peaks, 30 days, but reduced rigor.' Here are consequences.
Sponsor chooses Option A: Focus on Peak A (highest), 30 days, $50K. This is the approved integrated plan.
Can we reach Peak A in 30 days with $50K? Check: team skill, weather windows, equipment. Yes, feasible. Risk: acceptable.
Climbing team, logistics team, finance team all understand: Peak A only, 30 days, $50K. One integrated goal.
Day 15: Check progress vs. plan. Days to summit 2. Days remaining 15. On track. Budget spent $25K. Resources on pace.
Day 18: Bad weather. Need extra day. Scope fixed (Peak A), budget fixed ($50K), but timeline now 31 days. Escalate: sponsor approves 1-day extension OR we reduce rigor.

story.moral: Integration of planning is like balancing three mountains: **I**dentify constraints, **N**ote conflicts, **T**rade-off analysis, **E**xpress options, **G**et approval, **R**eview feasibility, **A**lign teams, **T**rack health, **E**scalate breaks.
